
An outdated messaging app encrypts secrets using RSA, but mistakenly uses only blum integers for its moduli. Can you decrypt this intercepted message? 3749105283642512056256350684297769721887160935718732462952086439215075852189351067713386456808274403715560439518401383614956073822165100002811399994773634


The flag format is flag{...}
n=6803053392114932237083190577500810774352210551108826561531457021563071853953092438521914967156128744675390209218272524497432896873720236788974873807224189, e=3838027334174407389965568682494804644940325579467402119946308468614987874149832142687012570480922773945657403683567179254248774283673239098393647541921589
The lower 104 bits of p are: 61011171815241603802838163217065037051

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{czs1fkz7}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3749105283642512056256350684297769721887160935718732462952086439215075852189351067713386456808274403715560439518401383614956073822165100002811399994773634
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6803053392114932237083190577500810774352210551108826561531457021563071853953092438521914967156128744675390209218272524497432896873720236788974873807224189, e=3838027334174407389965568682494804644940325579467402119946308468614987874149832142687012570480922773945657403683567179254248774283673239098393647541921589
The lower 104 bits of p are: 61011171815241603802838163217065037051
